chapter.title: Functions
chapter.para: Functions provide a way to reuse an expression at different points in your script.

row.entry: An instance function declaration without a body. The defining class must also be abstract. A concrete (non-abstract) class will need to override the function to provide a definition.
A bound function allows a bound context to extend into a function call.
An instance function can override the definition in its superclass if the override modifier is used.
The function can only be called from the package where it is defined. See Access Modifiers.
The function can only be called from the package where it is defined and from subclasses of the class where it is defined. See Access Modifiers.
The function can be called from anywhere. See Access Modifiers.

sect1.title: Kinds of Functions
sect1.para: Functions can be declared at the script level (script function) or inside a class (instance function). Local functions are not yet supported.

sect2.title: Script Functions
sect2.para: Script functions are declared at the top-level of a script, not inside a class definition. Script functions are visible throughout the entire script -- a member access expression is not needed.

para.programlisting: function square(x : Number) : Number { x * x } println( square(7) )

sect2.para: If access modifiers are added which make the script function visible outside the script, they may be accessed as members of the script. For example, if this is script Foo.f3:

para.programlisting: public function square(x : Number) : Number { x * x }

sect2.para: Then script Bar.f3 can access square:

sect2.title: Instance Functions
sect2.para: Instance functions are declared at the top-level of a class. Instance functions are visible through-out the entire script -- a member access expression is not needed within the class (or its subclasses) but is needed outside of the class.

sect1.title: Type Inference
sect1.para: Type inferencing can generally determine the return type of a function. In most cases the parameter types can be determined by type inference as well.
However, functions which, by virtue of their access modifiers, are visible outside the script should be explicitly typed.

sect1.title: Parameter passing
sect1.para: When called in a bound context, the parameters of a bound function are passed by reference and the return value is by reference as well. In all other cases, non-bound functions and bound functions called form non-bound contexts, parameters are passed by value and the the return value is by value.
